ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Chinese, basic situations like renting an apartment, writing letters, making calls, going to the airport, etc.
better grasp of spoken Chinese and listening Chinese
I developed fluent ability to navigate all of the most essential aspects of day-to-day life in China--especially from the perspective of a student studying abroad.
I developed better time managing skills, as well as more knowledge on Chinese Language.
Intermediate Chinese Level language skills comprising vocabulary, grammar, pronunciation etc.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Great instructors and fun class activities!

The class size is very small and conversational, making for exceptional practice and application time during each period. The class covers topics and lessons that are very practical for basic communication needs in a foreign country. 

Because the class is exclusively in Chinese, there are time when I (and other students) would not understand something and not be able to clarify the point with the teacher.

I think this course was very well put together. I felt like the smaller group setting for the classes was really beneficial to help each teacher connect with the students and help them focus on individual strengths and weaknesses in their learning. I think the course does not need any improvement as it is.

Strengths: great teachers, broad support system, very well organised, frequent and varied assessments.
Weaknesses: I would have liked a more systematic approach towards working on our pronunciation. We all realised it was lackluster, but there was no real space to work on it. This does not mean that we should allot class time, but perhaps the offer of an additional tutorial for those wanting to work on their pronunciation might be a good idea.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely! I found it a nice balance to my other classes, and the class atmosphere was relaxing at the same time as it encouraged us to learn.
I would recommend this course to another student but only if youre willing to put in the work!
Yes, if you are passionate about learning Chinese and are willing to put in the work to keep up with the course.
Yes, I enjoyed taking CHNS 130 and felt like it was a good language to learn for my language requirement.

Yes. The course is VERY well organised and it is frankly impossible not to greatly improve at Mandarin if you actually complete all the assignments. That being said, this is a high workload course. I would definitely advise you plan the rest of your schedule and its relative workload around this course rather than try to squeeze it into an already packed worksheet.
